block.p: U.N. Summit Meeting Ripples Through New York The gathering of world leaders at the United Nations formally gets under way today, but its effects were already being felt by New Yorkers and visitors alike who had to cope with traffic jams, motorcades, security precautions and demonstrations.

None of the parties in Israeli-Palestinian peace negotiations appeared optimistic that President Clinton could nudge the leaders closer to a deal when he meets with them individually in New York today.

U.N. Summit Meeting Ripples Through New York The gathering of world leaders at the United Nations formally gets under way today, but its effects were already being felt by New Yorkers and visitors alike who had to cope with traffic jams, motorcades, security precautions and demonstrations.

None of the parties in Israeli-Palestinian peace negotiations appeared optimistic that President Clinton could nudge the leaders closer to a deal when he meets with them individually in New York today.
Senate to Vote on China Trade The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, said he would try to schedule a final vote on the China trade bill by the end of next week.
Rating Religious Freedom China has increasingly responded with harassment, extortion, detention and torture as more Chinese seek to practice religious faiths, a State Department report said.

Conservative Party Platform The leader of Britain's Conservative Party, William Hague, set out 100 policy proposals that the party hopes will help it win the national election. They include holding off consideration of adopting the euro.
German Minister Injured Germany's defense minister was briefly hospitalized after a security barrier struck his car as he arrived for a ceremony at the Pentagon.
No Aid for Haiti Elections The United States will not send observers or financial aid for Haiti's November presidential elections.

A Costly Decision to Be Made Suspicions that they are seeing sketchy evidence for a long-sought particle has put physicists in Geneva in a quandary over whether to build a $4 billion particle accelerator or continue using current equipment.

Bush Prescription Plan Is Overhaul of Medicare Gov. George W. Bush proposed an overhaul of the 35-year-old Medicare program that would encourage recipients to choose subsidized private health insurance plans offering prescription drug coverage and would also pay the full cost of drug coverage for the low-income elderly.
Health insurance premiums are rising from 10 percent to 30 percent, suggesting that apart from the most restrictive, bare-bones H.M.O.'s, managed care is no longer keeping medical costs down.

Gore's Economic Vision The Gore campaign issued an economic blueprint for the next decade, including a $300 billion rainy day fund, a commitment to eliminate the national debt and goals that included increasing family incomes, reducing poverty and narrowing the gap in wages between men and women.

Democrats Prepare to Dig In Democrats returning from Congressional recess said they would remain on Capitol Hill as long as necessary this year to push their agenda, which includes pressing their proposals for overhauling managed care and raising the minimum wage.

Expanding Retirement Savings The Senate Finance Committee chairman, William V. Roth Jr., namesake of the popular Roth I.R.A., proposed legislation to create a similar 401(k) plan and raise contribution limits for individual retirement accounts and 401(k) plans.

Scientist Presses for Bail Lawyers for a former Los Alamos scientist, Wen Ho Lee, who is accused of mishandling classified information, asked a federal appeals court to reject government arguments against granting him bail.

Few Gains in Basic Skills American students read no better than their predecessors a generation ago, and their basic math skills have advanced only slightly, according to an analysis of standardized tests given since the early 1970's.

Ex-Doctor to Admit To Killing 3 Patients Michael J. Swango, 45, a former physician accused of poisoning patients from Ohio to Zimbabwe but who continued to find medical jobs, will plead guilty in federal court today to charges that he murdered three patients at a Long Island hospital in 1993, prosecutors said.
Bypassing the Tappan Zee Seventy-seven commuters used a new ferry service to cross from Haverstraw, in Rockland County, N.Y., to make a Metro-North train connection for the ride into Manhattan.

Interview From Peruvian Jail Lori Berenson, speaking in an interview conducted in March 1999 but just now made public, described the harsh conditions of her confinement and accused the authorities of mistreating prisoners.

Truman Grandson Killed by Cab William W. Daniel, 41, a grandson of President Truman, died on Monday from injuries he suffered when a cab hit him on Park Avenue in the East 70's last weekend, his family said. He was the son of Margaret Truman, the novelist and only child of the president, and Clifton Daniel, the former managing editor of The New York Times, who died in February.
Clyde Sukeforth The Brooklyn Dodger scout and manager who brought Jackie Robinson to his historic meeting with Branch Rickey, the Dodgers' president, he was 98.

Venus Williams to Face Hingis Venus Williams beat Nathalie Tauziat, 6-4, 1-6, 6-1, to advance to a semifinal match in the United States Open against Martina Hingis, who beat Monica Seles, 6-0, 7-5. Nicolas Kiefer defeated the third-seeded Magnus Norman, 6-2, 6-7 (3), 6-1, 6-3.

Inquiry Into Fatal Tire Flaws The Bridgestone/Firestone tire defect blamed for 88 deaths, mainly in Ford Explorers, eluded detection because it occurred infrequently, even though it proved deadlier than many problems that occur more often in vehicles, Ford and Congressional investigators said. It was also disclosed that Ford had replaced tires in Saudi Arabia and elsewhere without notifying federal officials.

AOL-Time Warner Merger Government regulators were said to be finishing work on a list of conditions they want to impose on the $165 billion merger of America Online and Time Warner. A leading concern was said to be a requirement that the merged company would open its cable television systems to other companies that want to offer high-speed Internet services.

New Leader for Health Insurer John W. Rowe, 56, chief executive of the Mount Sinai N.Y.U. Medical Center and Health System, was named president and chief executive of Aetna U.S. Healthcare, the country's largest health insurer. Dr. Rowe oversaw the Mt. Sinai-N.Y.U. hospital merger.
Editorials: First, three big debates; the world's meeting place; where time lay frozen.
